prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For refusing to buy any of my family members a christmas gift?
Now, based off of the title, you probably already think “Damn, this kid’s an asshole.” But here’s some context.

The week before Christmas, I received a $400 target gift card I won in a drawing.  I bragged about it on Instagram, where my sister follows me on, and of course, she saw it. She gave me a phone call and asked me who gave it to me, and I explain the situation, and tell her specifically NOT TO TELL MOM, as I knew it was bad enough that my sister knew already. She hangs up, and a few minutes later, my mother comes bursting into my room. She asks to see the gift card, and I hand it to her. She gives it back, then she says, obnoxiously, “You have to get something for me and (Sister’s name), That frustrated me enough, but I agreed, (I am VERY conservative, especially with my money.) 

Then when I was at target, getting my stuff plus what I WAS gonna get for my mom and sister, I get a phone call from my mom. 

Mom: “Oh, also, you have to get something for (Cousin 1’s name) and (Cousin 2’s name,) as well. Be thoughtful, don’t just get something cheap.” She said, even more obnoxiously 

(We were visiting my Uncle and Aunt for christmas, and my cousins are 6 and 2, so why the hell would I need to spend that much money on two more people I don’t and won’t see often?)

Me: “No thanks.” I then hung up the phone and ignored the rest of my mom’s texts and phone calls.

I spoiled myself, changing my mind about getting anyone else anything, because of how obnoxious everyone was being towards me after finding out what I had, so I spoiled myself. Bought myself a pair of airpods, GTA V, PlayStation Plus,a cheap laptop to do work on, and some new wrestling gear. Also bought a buddy of mine a bluetooth speaker, and spent the rest on candy and whatnot. 

Walked home and my mother was expecting that I got everyone a gift. Boy, was she shocked (despite our last phone call.) I got an ass chewing and she tried to guilt trip me, (unsuccessfully.) 

We were arguing then I just said “Maybe if you weren’t being so greedy about the situation, and kept your paws off of my money, I wouldn’t have changed my mind about getting you guys something!” (My exact words with some stuttering in it,) 

She then yelled at me a final time, marched to her room, and slammed her door. 

Typing that first paragraph made my blood boil, and reminded me of why I’m gonna keep all future assets private to me and me only. 

I’m 15 years old, if that will affect your criticism at all. 





"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is about Christmas gifts and money. The author is 15 years old, which might be important because they're a teenager, maybe not in a position to spend money as they wish yet.

The author won a $400 gift card and posted about it on Instagram. Their sister saw it and told the mom, even though the author had told the sister not to. Then the mom insisted that the author should buy gifts for the sister, the author's mom, and two cousins. The author felt pressured and ended up not buying gifts for the family but bought things for themselves and a friend. The mom got upset, leading to an argument.

First, the author's parents might have expectations that children should share or give gifts to family members during Christmas. The author's mom was being pushy, adding more people to the list even though the cousins are young and not seen often. The author is being conservative with their money, which is understandable, especially if they're still a minor. However, depending on the family dynamics, parents might expect their kids to participate in gift-giving as a family tradition.

The author did tell the mom not to tell others about the gift card but the sister did, leading to the mom getting involved. The author might feel that the mom overstepped by demanding gifts. The mom's reaction could be seen as overbearing, especially adding cousins to the list. However, the author could have communicated their discomfort earlier instead of snapping after the fact.

The author is 15, so maybe they're not in a position to manage such a large amount of money yet, and parents might have a right to guide them. But they're also at an age where they might want more independence. The argument could be about boundaries and respect. The mom might feel entitled to the gift card money since it's in a family setting, but the author might see it as their own.

In terms of right and wrong, it depends on perspective. The author might be wrong in not considering family expectations, but the mom is wrong in being pushy and adding unexpected recipients. The author's decision to buy themselves stuff instead could be seen as selfish, but their frustration is understandable given the pressure. The key issue is the lack of prior communication. The author could have discussed their limits with the mom before making decisions. However, the mom's demands were also excessive. So, maybe both have some fault, but the question is whether the author is in the wrong.

Considering the options, the answer could be B (No, the author is not in the wrong) because the mom was overstepping, and the author has a right to manage their own money. However, the author could have handled it more gracefully. But given the context, the author's actions are justified. Alternatively, maybe A (Yes, in the wrong) because ignoring the mom's requests and not buying gifts could hurt family feelings. But the mom's behavior was also problematic. Given the scenario, the author's stance might be more about standing up for personal boundaries, so B might be the answer.
